meta.name: description
meta.content: City Academy, a Salt Lake City public charter school, offers tuition-free education to middle and high school students. Schedule a campus visit today.

div.h1: Tuition-Free Public Charter School in Salt Lake City
div.p: City Academy is a tuition-free public charter school conveniently located in downtown Salt Lake City at 555 E. 200 S. Educators from the University of Utahâs College of Education founded our school in 2000. City Academy is an independent, public middle school and high school for grades 7 through 12 chartered by the Utah State Board of Education. Our school has small classes so that our capable and highly qualified teachers can work more personally with each student and engage them in meaningful learning. What gives us an edge over other Salt Lake City high schools is that we offer the prestigious Cambridge International Examinations as our advanced placement program.
Our students have a personalized meaningful education

div.h3: What Parents and Students Say About Us

div.div: Brian Rollo Parent

div.p: I am very happy with the decision to send my daughter to City Academy! She just completed her first year and it was a huge success. They really care about and pay attention to the kids. For example, Sonia, the Executive Director, noticed that my daughter was bored in her math class and immediately worked with her to find a more challenging class. I also really love that the school is accepting of all kids, even those that might struggle to find their spot in a standard high school. I highly recommend City Academy as a school that will bring out the best in your kids.

div.div: Christina Phelps Parent

div.p: City Academy is the best. It is a great community to be a part of, the teachers are dedicated, my son has many friends from different backgrounds, and they are all really good, happy kids. I have also come to know many parents and they too share the love for City Academy. If you would like to see your child receive an outstanding education and the tools required for a successful future, you will not be disappointed with City Academy!!!!

div.div: Wanda Robinson Parent

div.p: Have I told you all again lately how happy I am about the concepts, ideals and practices of City Academy? My daughter has grown leaps and bounds in confidence just two months into the year. She is happy about the new things she is learning.

div.div: Marcus Erwin Former Student

div.p: Teachers actually care about you here. They will e-mail you, call you and get with you face to face. The teachers are just awesome.

div.div: Lucas Hayes Student

div.p: I like how everyone has the chance to get involved.

div.div: Shelly Albaum Parent

div.p: Our daughter was a gifted student, but she did not like school. We have tried public schools, another charter school, and even home-schooling. Nothing came close to City Academy in terms of simultaneously supporting and challenging her. I think City Academyâs success is due about equally to their integrated approach to learning, and the quality and dedication of the faculty.

div.div: Megan Student

div.p: Last year, when I got out of the Cambridge testing, after writing three essays in two hours about European world history, it was a totally different kind of relief. I was so proud that I did something like that. Thatâs like one of those crazy Hogwarts things that you donât think kids actually do. You knowâwrite three essays in two hoursâbut I did it, and I got an A. And, it was awesome, and it felt really, really good.

div.h2: Providing Tuition-Free Education to Dedicated Students
div.p: Welcome to City Academy, a charter school in Salt Lake City with a reputation for academic excellence. We offer tuition-free schooling, which centers on effective and innovative learning. Students can expect the best from our school. Our small class sizes allow each student to get more individual attention.
div.h3: Open to Salt Lake Valley Students
div.p: Parents in Salt Lake Valley donât need to look far for an excellent high school or middle school in Salt Lake City. Our public charter school caters to both middle and high school students. We commit to delivering the quality education parents want for their children. Parents can count on us to provide both an enhanced curriculum and personalized guidance to their children.

We want students to demonstrate and develop competencies and knowledge in challenging academics while becoming lifelong learners. We accomplish this by emphasizing investigative process and inquiry in our courses. On top of that, highly qualified teachers present questions that engage students in various areas, including problem-solving, creative and critical thinking, and issue-based learning.
div.h3: Getting High School Students Ready for College
div.p: City Academy is also a college preparatory high school in Salt Lake City. Our goal is to help students successfully meet the demands of higher education. Our curriculum includes courses designed to get students in 9th grade and above ready for advanced-placement courses in college. If your student is looking for AP classes in the Salt Lake City area, talk to us about our various options. Our school is a great fit for those wanting to prepare for a higher learning institution either locally or out of state.

Want to learn more about our public charter school? We encourage you to arrange a campus visit. Weâll show you why many parents are excited about the quality of education we provide to our students.
Make City Academy your Salt Lake City high school of choice. Get in touch with our office today for more details.

div.div: City Academy studentsâin their own words

ul.li: âCity Academy is the best school Iâve ever been to. Itâs super nice.â
âCity Academyâs Cambridge International advanced placement program is four times more interesting than regular AP programs. Itâs intuitive and discussion based.â
âCity Academy is super welcoming and nice.â
âCity Academyâs students are totally one cohesive group.â
âAt my other school, it felt like the teachers were worn out.â
âAt City Academy during lunch, I can sit at any table. There are no social groups at City Academy.â
âThe things I like about City Academy are the personalization, the classes are small, and the in-depth education.â

div.div: Ashley Kennedy is among City Academyâs brightest stars.Â Since she graduated in 2014, sheâs earned bachelorâs and masterâs degrees from the University of Utahâs College of Engineering, and is now pursuing her J.D. degree from the University of Utahâs S.J. Quinney College of Law (sheâs expected to graduate in 2022).Â During her time at the University, she received an Honors at Entrance Scholarship, the Ivan B. Cutler Endowed Scholarship, the Jeff and Kori Gunn Scholarship and the Frank E. and Jane D. Wagstaff Endowed Scholarship.Â She also made the Deanâs List in Fall 2014, and Fall 2015 through Spring 2018.
What year did you graduate from City Academy?
What would you tell a student today if he or she was considering going to City Academy?

Do it.Â Absolutely do it.Â It will be the best thing you can do for yourself.Â The teachers are the best in Utah, the material is engaging, and the extracurriculars are fun.Â The experience that you have there will set you up for success for the rest of your life.
What is your fondest memory or memories of the time you spent at City Academy?

div.p: I enjoyed Mock Trial and â believe it or not â the extended after-school class periods for my A-level courses. It was fun being in an environment where everyone is eager to learn and the teachers are excited to teach.

div.div: How did City Academy prepare you for your future endeavors?

div.p: I was actually thinking about this the other day as I was in one of my legal writing courses.Â The A-level writing style taught me quite a lot about persuasive writing, especially in terms of supporting an argument. It has given me an advantage over my other law school classmates.Â Mock Trial has also helped me in law school.Â I am able to articulate myself well under pressure, which is helpful during Socratic dialogue.

div.div: Why did you decide to come to City Academy in the first place?

div.p: I was looking for more of a challenge, and the A-level courses were exactly what I needed. The smaller class sizes and individualized attention was definitely an advantage. It was an amazing experience knowing that my teachers actually cared about my success and it was a privilege to be taught by them.

div.div: How was City Academy different from other schools?

div.p: City Academy is much more student-focused than other schools. As I mentioned previously, the teachers were incredible and truly cared about their classes. It was fun to be taught by people that were passionate about their jobs. It certainly helped my interest in each subject. Charlie Johnsonâs English class specifically comes to mind.

div.div: If you were part of the Cambridge program, what impact did it have on you?

div.p: The Cambridge program had a huge impact on me and my career-path.Â It helped me realize that I am fully capable and eager to do hard work.Â It also showed me that I am able to engage with material that is foreign to me and have confidence that I will be able to master it.Â This is a major reason why I majored in engineering in college.

div.div: What have you done since graduating from City Academy (include any degrees/honors/scholarships youâve earned, any jobs youâve held)?

div.p: I attended the University of Utah, where I earned both my B.S. and my M.S. degrees in Materials Science and Engineering.Â I am now attending law school at the University of Utah.Â I have been working at an Intellectual Property law firm (TraskBritt) as a technical advisor/law clerk.

div.div: What are your plans for the future?

div.p: I plan to earn my JD and enter the field of intellectual property prosecution and litigation

div.div: Did you take advantage of City Academyâs $1,000 scholarship program?

div.p: I did.Â It certainly helped me out with my undergraduate tuition.

div.div: Ms. Schriever
What accomplishments are you most proud of and why?

div.p: After four years and much hard work, I was able to complete a masterâs of Mathematics.Â It showed me that no matter where I am in life, I am capable of learning and achieving great things.Â The icing on the cake was that three of my children graduated with their bachelorâs degree at the same time I received my masterâs degree.

div.div: What is one of your best memories from your childhood?

div.p: I grew up in Maryland and a few weeks every summer we would have fireflies dancing on our property.Â We would spend magical evenings chasing the fireflies.

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: I wanted to become a math teacher because I wanted to share my joy in discovering the beauty and patterns in the world around us that can only be understood through math.

div.div: Ms. Razmic
Whatâs on your bucket list?

div.p: Some things on my bucket list include traveling to the countries of Croatia and Norway from which my families migrated to the U.S., seeing the northern lights, going to the summer Olympics to watch diving and going to the U.S. Open menâs final for tennis.

div.div: What is one valuable lesson you have ever learned?

div.p: A valuable lesson that I have learned is that without warning, life, our dreams and future plans can change in a split second but we are still responsible for our own happiness. Never give up and have a backup plan!

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: My father was a teacher and coach and I knew at a young age that I would follow in his footsteps. I took a couple of detours first but have no regrets.

div.div: Ms. Disberger
What is one of your best memories from your childhood?

div.p: One of my best memories from my childhood was building a âcat hotelâ in our shed for our farm cats with my sister. We made little rooms out of any old supplies we could find and decorated it with fabric and flowers. Watching our kittens explore our creation was a joy!

div.div: What would you most like to learn and why?

div.p: I would most like to learn how Virtual Reality computer software works because our future is more and more computer dependent and it would be amazing to be able to translate the ideas in my head into something that other people could interact with.

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: My mom inspired me to become a teacher. She has been teaching high school family and consumer sciences for 23 years and has always impressed me by her care for students and her enthusiasm for learning. Hearing all of the ways she touches the lives of students inspires me to be the best teacher I can be.

div.div: Mrs. Sparkman
What is one of your best memories from your childhood?

div.p: One of my best memories from childhood is on crisp fall days in Minnesota when the autumn leaves blanketed the ground, I would help my grandpa rake the leaves into piles that seemed at least three feet tall.Â After the piles were made, I would stand on the edge and fall backwards with arms spread wide and let the crisp leaves catch my fall.

div.div: What is one valuable lesson you have ever learned?

div.p: One of the most valuable lessons Iâve learned is that failure is only defeat if you stop trying.Â Failures lead to successes which are all the sweeter when youâve worked hard for them.

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: I come from a long line of teachers in my extended family and have always loved helping others to understand what they are learning.Â My high school creative writing teacher inspired me to become a teacher because she was compassionate, approachable, and knowledgeable.Â She made me feel important, like I wasnât just another number in the hundreds of students that came through her door.Â I want to share my passion for inquiry, critical thinking, creativity, science, and learning with everyone in my life.Â Students are our future and I feel blessed and honored to create a learning environment where we can explore the world around us.

div.div: Alyssa Atkinson
What is on your bucket list?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span: Visiting all the national parks in Utah is definitely on my bucket listâthere are so many in this one state!

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span: I decided to become a teacher when I helped teach my 3-year-old brother learn how to read. I would race home from 3rd grade every day, super excited to work with him; thatâs when I realized I would love to teach when I grew up.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: Working at City Academy is fabulous because the students and faculty create the environment they want to be in; everyone is willing to jump in and make themselves and the school community better every day.

div.div: Kathy Beeckel
What accomplishments are you most proud of and why?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: The accomplishments I am most proud of are the ones that took the most effort and courage: diving off 30-foot cliffs, finishing a marathon with a bad knee, earning my degree while raising three sons by myself, becoming fluent in another language, and simply overcoming lifeâs tough challenges.

div.div: What's on your bucket list?

div.p: My unofficial bucket list includes: becoming truly fluent in Russian and learning other languages; exploring more of the world and its cultures; learning how to cook a greater variety of ethnic foods; learning how to scuba dive; taking horseback riding lessons and ballroom dance classes (not together-J); climbing some more mountainsâ¦ Thereâs just too much to do!

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: One feature I like about teaching here at City Academy is the smaller classes which allow me to get to know the students better and to offer more individualized attention when needed. Another important and enjoyable aspect of working here is the ability to work with and have constant collaboration with my colleagues.Â

div.div: Jo Bradbury
What accomplishments are you most proud of and why

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: I am very proud of my accomplishments as a teacher and an artist.Â More specifically, I am proud that I received a scholarship to Pratt Institute in Brooklyn in 2012.Â I am also proud of the fact that I won First Place in the Statewide Ogden Eccles Art Show in 2009.Â That was a huge honor and made me feel proud in my accomplishments. Another accomplishment I am proud of is the fact that when I first came to City Academy, there was no art room, and only a part-time art teacher position,Â I am proud to have grown City Academyâs Art Department to the great place where it is today, which includes one full- and one part-time art teacher, a fully functional art classroom with all the supplies we need, and a range of over 75 art students!

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: My father and mother are both teachers, and I always loved art, so it seemed like the logical solution.Â I also love people and sharing my passion for art with students.Â I love being in the same space of admiration for something visual as my students and we are all appreciating the same thing.Â That symbiosis is such a fun place to be!

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: What I love about City Academy is that itâs so inclusive.Â I love knowing all my students as well as the vast majority of students in the building.Â I love knowing all my fellow faculty members better than I ever did at my other school.Â I am proud that our program has grown so much and I love that it is now a part of City Academy culture.Â It is a great school!

div.div: Gisselle Castro
Whatâs on your bucket list?

div.p: Backpack all of Eastern Europe.

div.div: What is one of your best memories from your childhood?

div.p: When my sister and I were little, every weekend my parents would take us to the beach in Honduras and we would always go snorkeling and collect sea shells.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: What I love working at City Academy is the positive environment there is, and the dedication and commitment the staff and teachers have for every student to graduate and pursue higher education.

div.div: Kim Deem
What's on your bucket list?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: An item on my bucket list that I hope to accomplish is to volunteer for Ski Patrol at a local ski resort.

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: I have always excelled at athletics and it was a big part of my life growing up. I also have a passion for health and living an active lifestyle. It brings me a sense of fulfillment and joy when I have the opportunity to help others succeed, and I love sharing my passions with those around me. Thatâs why I chose teaching as a profession.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: What I enjoy about teaching at City Academy is the opportunity to get to know students on a more personalized level. I feel that City Academy is a learning community where our students have access to a more customized learning experience based on their abilities and needs.

div.div: Matt DeVoll
Whatâs on your bucket list?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span:
I love to travel internationally and see different customs and cultures so my bucket list of trips to take include; England, Australia and Africa.Â My trips to Istanbul, Germany, and Paris have been amazing.
I would love to learn how to make all 18 holes in golf connect to an awesome score.Â My tendency is to play well for a few holes, blowup on a hole and then try to get back on track for a decent round of golf.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: I really like working at City Academy because I have the opportunity to meet so many new students and work with them on areas such as college and careers or simply overcoming obstacles that they are faced with in life.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.div: Hana Jabr
What do you feel passionate about?

div.p: I was inspired by many amazing teachers that I had throughout middle and high school. Mrs. Coon, my AP Literature teacher, inspired me to embrace my passion for literature and writing. That passion is something I strive to pass on to my own students.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: I love the small class sizes and seminar-style Cambridge courses. I feel like I am able to get to know each and every student that I teach.

div.div: Alla McCamey
What accomplishments are you most proud of and why?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: For 23 years of my teaching in Ukraine, five of my former students have become teachers of HIstory/ESLâthe subjects I taught them at school.Â I hope to inspire some American students as well!

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: Iâve become a teacher in memory of those awesome people whoâve done their best educating and teaching me HOW TO BE HAPPY AT SCHOOL.Â It was not that easy to work with me during my school time!Â Itâs my tribute to them and my promise to always keep to make at least one more shy and non-socialized kid feel happy and safe at school.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: Iâm still new here but I already love the whole atmosphere and spirit of City Academy: creative, researching, open-minded, sincere and family-like.Â Itâs a true Academy of Knowledge and Talent and a wonderful place to teach!

div.div: Dennis Pedersen
What is one valuable lesson you have learned?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span: One of the most valuable things Iâve learned is how to learn for myself.

div.div: What is your favorite journey?

div.p: My favorite journey is the journey I am taking through life, which I hope has still a lot to offer.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: What I like about teaching at City Academy is being able to offer my students the tools that they may need to learn from during their journey through their life.

div.div: Karen Peterson-Kunigk
What accomplishments are you most proud of and why?

div.p: I donât think very much about being proud of accomplishments, I suppose, but I think one thing I did at university was worth being proud of because it triggered so many unexpectedly wonderful happenings in my life: I knew I could not have a second fully paid Honorâs scholarship to a study abroad program, but I applied anyway, crunching in two double intensive German courses in order to be eligible. This led to me getting that scholarship after all, traveling to Europe for the first time in my life: studying in Vienna, Austria for a summer, finishing my bachelorâs degree not only in French but in German as well, then off to working in Germany to learn German better, receiving a Fulbright Scholarship, getting married and staying in Europe for 22 years â oh my! My life changed. Oops.

div.div: What was your favorite journey?

div.p: My favorite journey started in the middle of the night in Berlin (Iron Curtain timesâ¦), driving through East Germany, where Russian guards took my passport for five hours, then through West Germany where the best part of the journey was to come: I got off the train at the French border, walked across a bridge into France, took meandering country trains into Brittany and the forest of BrocÃ©liande of Arthurian legend. There, instead of traveling around France hitting all of the tourist spots, I changed my itinerary. I ended up staying for two weeks inside the forest, where I was shown circles of standing stones by a forest dweller, saw the tomb of Merlin, got teased by fairies as I tried to escape sorceress Morgaineâs Vale of No Return (entering was simple, but I was apparently not pure enough of heart to leave easily). When I finally emerged, I drank from the natural Spring of BÃ©renton, unwittingly causing a tumultuous torrential rain to occur, took refuge under the 450-plus year old Master Beech tree of Ponthus until it would tolerate me no longer and was extremely happy to have a roof over my head that night.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: I really just like teaching the students here at City Academy because the subjects I teach inherently lead students to think in different ways than they ever have before, (maybe eat, drink and feel in different ways than they ever would have believed possible!) which is always very exciting for me to be a part of.

div.div: Gail Richardson
What accomplishment am I most proud of and why?

div.p: It is a tied between getting a masterâs degree and being in the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

Masterâs degree â A masterâs degree sounds far smarter than I think I am.Â It was a fun degree to get in spite of the huge work load. I learned things that I felt I should have known sooner; Much of what I learned was truly fascinating; and some was downright scary.Â Once I finished, I realized that although many of the women in my family have bachelorâs degrees only two of us have masterâs degrees.Â Thatâs kind of cool.
Mormon Tabernacle Choir

I auditioned for the choir almost on a whim.Â The audition was hard and scary.Â I knew some people audition three or four times before they got in.Â Nothing musical has ever come easily for me, so I didnât think this would.Â In the end I got in my first try.Â This choir was a lot of work, almost 20 hours a week.Â But it was an absolutely fabulous experience.Â I got to do things I had only dreamed of, including performing in some of the most famous concert halls in the world.Â It was a life-altering experience.

div.div: What would you most like to learn and why?

div.p: I want to learn to play a variety of musical instruments.Â My next two will be violin and cello.Â I have both instruments, but havenât started on them yet.Â Previously I learned to play piano, organ, flute, clarinet, guitar, ukulele and harp. That doesnât mean I am great at all of them, but have played them enough to be reasonably competent.Â Of course, I have also worked to learn to sing.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: I love that I know most of the students in this school.Â My teaching here is student focused, NOT program focused.Â No fund raisers, no crazy Christmas time performance schedule, no choir tours to arrange, and no finances to keep (formals, school fees, tour payments, etc.).

I get to know and work with my students to help them become the best musician they can. I get to teach them about a variety of musical interests including piano, guitar, choir, composition, history and of course how all of this affects their brain.

div.class: pum pum-overlay pum-theme-2990 pum-theme-lightbox popmake-overlay pum-overlay-disabled click_open
pum-container popmake theme-2990 pum-responsive pum-responsive-small responsive size-small pum-position-fixed
div.div: Gaby Saxton
What accomplishments are you most proud of and why?

div.p: I am proud of my masterâs in education, the fact that I am licensed to teach first grade through twelfth grade, and I am endorsed in theater, history, educational technology, and English as a second language. I also tested in the top 15 percent on my Praxis Teacherâs Exam in the country, andÂ I won awards from the Salt Lake City School District in English and science as a middle school teacher. Obviously, I am proud all my hard work and studying and working hard, paid off. I am way more than just a theater teacher.
I am also immensely proud of my two amazing children! They are hardworking, talented and kind men.

div.div: What is one valuable lesson you have ever learned?

div.p: That what we say, and do, as teachers impacts students for their whole lives. There is no such thing as a âmeaningless moment.â All moments we have with children carry weight, and we can make learning a wonderful or painful experience. What we do and say as teachers matters. I want to make a good impact on childrenâs lives.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: I love getting to know the students. Our low student-to-teacher numbers enable us to really get to know our kids. They are not just a number. I also love how welcoming we are and that we embrace students as individuals. We are an open, diverse and inclusive school. That is at the core of who I am as an educator, and City Academy not only embraces, but celebrates, that philosophy.

div.div: Lillian Scoville
What is one valuable lesson you have learned?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span: One of the most valuable lessons I have learned comes from a quote by a very old lady I know.Â She says, âEveryone struggles, be kind.â A favorite memory from my childhood is a gift of experiences from my dad.Â Sometimes when I was feeling sad, he would get out two baseball mitts and a baseball and invite me to play catch with him.Â I was never very good at it but we had fun and it took my mind off of whatever was troubling me. It allowed me to face whatever was hard for me with more optimism and a fresh perspective when we were finished playing.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span: I love teaching at City Academy because the teachers and other staff I work with are truly remarkable people who support me in doing my best work just as they support the students in doing their best learning every day.

div.div: Jan Shepherd
What is one valuable lesson you have learned?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span: A valuable lesson Iâve learned is to be grateful for what I have and to try to live in the moment.Â

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: #222222;

p.span: I enjoy working behind the scenes at City Academy and doing my best to make things run smoothly for all.Â Â Â Â

div.div: Jose Shirley
If you could describe yourself in three words what would they be?

div.p: Awesome, fun, funny.

div.div: What is one of your best memories from your childhood?

div.p: Going camping in the Colorado mountains with my family.

div.div: What do you like about working at City Academy?

div.p: I always have something to do, it is always upbeat and I love talking with the students here.

div.div: Kayla Sudweeks
What would you most like to learn and why?

div.p: I have always wanted to learn another language. When Iâm not teaching or making art, I spend my time reading. I have recently become a huge fan of both Gabriel GarcÃ­a MÃ¡rquez and Pablo Neruda. I would love to be able to read their work in the original Spanish language.

div.div: What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: For as long as I can remember, I have wanted to go into education. However, when I started my BFA at the University of Utah, I did so not anticipating to teach art at the secondary level. It wasnât until I took an art education class with Dr. Beth Krensky that I began to grasp the importance of sharing my love of art with others. It was in that class I first experienced the work of Tim Rollins and K.O.S. (Kids of Survival). After seeing the art generated by Rollins and his students, I felt the need to pursue teaching more seriously.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: Teaching at City Academy has given me an opportunity to share my love of art and making with students and other colleagues in ways that are most authentic to me. This involves experimental drawing and sculpture. Because the classes tend to be on the smaller side, I am able to assess what individual students need, what their strengths are, and tailor my teaching to challenge and support each studentâs artistic growth.

div.div: Dr. Sonia Woodbury
What inspired you to become a teacher?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: My inspiration for becoming a teacher was my mother who was also a teacher, and of course my first teacher.

div.div: What is your favorite journey?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: I love traveling and I donât have a favorite journey because I am always most excited by planning my next one.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

span.style: font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; color: black;

p.span: I am a founding partner of City Academy and I have loved coming to work every day for the last 19 years because of the committed caring adults and students that I get to work with.

div.class: pum pum-overlay pum-theme-2990 pum-theme-lightbox popmake-overlay pum-overlay-disabled click_open

div.div: Ashlee Harms
What inspired you to become a teacher?

div.p: School has felt like home for me since I first stepped into a classroom many years ago as a student myself. Iâve been fortunate to have always known my goal in life: to become an educator, although at times it has felt as if though teaching is simply in my bones. Alongside a natural love for learning from and teaching others, famous authors, poets, and playwriters organically created a deep appreciation for literature and language within me. Literature showed me what it is to be human, what it is not to be human, and everything in between, and I felt it would be a crime for me to not share everything that I have learned about English Language Arts with future generations for them to learn from as well.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: One aspect about City Academy, which is known for its small class sizes, that I enjoy is that it emboldens teachers and students to flourish because every student is known. Having strengths, recognizing and growing in weaknesses, and general individuality is encouraged at City Academy, which all certainly enhance the educational experience for all involved.

div.div: Bruce Abe
Who are your favorite writers?

div.p: My favorite writers are Kim Stanley Robinson, Neal Stephenson, Lawrence Block, Donald Westlake, Terry Pratchett, Robert Frost, Taylor Mali, Atul Gawande, Malcolm Gladwell, Stephen Jay Gould, Patrick McManus, Dave Barry, Bill Watterson, Garry Trudeau, Randall Munroe, Barack Obama, Martin Luther King, Jr., Francesca Lia Block, Shannon Hale, and Daniel Pinkwater.

div.div: What is one of your best memories from your childhood?

div.p: I loved the time I spent fishing with my father.Â It was a quiet, peaceful time on a beautiful river, rarely interrupted by fish.Â We often came home with a bucket of cherries.

div.div: What do you like about teaching or working at City Academy?

div.p: I love the power each person at City Academy has to shape the school.Â Everybody can take on as much responsibility as they can handle, and grow to meet the challenge.
